Revert hack to value readers

This change makes value readers be resolved from DI everywhere (instead of just for query) such that different data stores can use different value reader implementations. SQL Server is set to use the object array value reader, which never calls the generic methods that are not supported on Mono, and which is currently the only value reader supported by query. This allows the hack to the typed value reader to be reverted, and sets things up so that other providers can use the typed reader as intended. Note that query still needs to be updated to work with the typed value reader before it can be used across the stack.

Extend read-only semantics per store generation discussion

Note: the naming of the concepts and whether or not they should be in an enum can be discussed in API review.

This change adds the concept of being read-only before saving a new entity as well as the concept of being read-only when updating a new entity. It also moves the check to happen as part of SaveChanges so that properties can go through a temporary state of being modified. Key values cannot go through this temporary state since the state manager relies on their values not changing.

Also added functional tests for all combinations of read-only flags and store generated patterns.

Use core Identity concept and convention for SQL Server keys

Core model building now has a convention to set StoreGeneratedPattern.Identity for non-composite primary keys that are not themselves a dependent property of some other key. This information can now be used by SQL Server instead of it having its own convention to do exactly the same thing.

Fix to #1927 - Query :: data corruption for queries with filter and && operator where one side is client eval and another is server eval

Problem is that for predicates with && operator, for which one side was client eval and the other was server eval we would only process the server eval part. This could lead to data corruption (i.e. query returning more rows than intended)

Fix is to handle top level && operation differently - splitting predicate into two Where operations, one on client and one on server. This is done only for && operation and only for top level. If client eval is needed at any point and the top level expression is not AndAlso, the entire predicate will be evaluated on the client.

Fix to 1742 - sometimes we produce invalid parameter name.

Problem is that for some (quite complicated) cases we would produce invalid parameter name. We try to generate the parameter name based ProperyInfo/FieldInfo path of the MemberExpression. Most of the time this is correct, but sometimes compiler can generate names like:
((QueryBugsTest+<>c__DisplayClass21_0).CS$<>8__locals1).details).LastName, which would produce name with invalid characters (e.g. CS$<>8__locals1_details_LastName)

Fix is to remove the compiler generated prefix.

Fixes #1842

Enhance the ForeignKeyPropertyDiscoveryConvention to choose the best candidate for the principal end of a non-self-referencing one-to-one relationship.
The dependent entity type will be choosen according to the following heuristics:
1. Entity type with non-shadow properties that can be used in the foreign key and are not in the primary key
2. Entity type without navigation
3. Entity type which primary key is not principal in any relationship
4. Second entity type by alphabetical order

Fix to Issues #1760 and #1830
#1760 - Query :: complex filter containing boolean expressions may produce invalid sql
#1830 - Query :: simplify negated expressions in query predicate

#1760:
Problem is when comparing expressions which are not simple (constant, parameter, column), e.g
products.Where(p => p.Discontinued == (p.ProductID > 100)). Naive translation produces invalid sql.

Fix is to expand those comparisons like so:
(a == b) => (a && b) || (!a && !b)
(a != b) => (!a && b) || (a && !b)

This is done before sql generation for perf reasons (result tree gets cached, sql does not).

#1830:
Since #1760 introduces additional (negated) expressions, we want to optimize them as much as possible.
This checkin handles the following optimizations:
!(!a) => a
!a == b => a != b
!a != b => a == b
!(a && b) => !a || !b
!(a || b) => !a && !b
!(a > b) => a <= b
!(a >= b) => a < b
!(a < b) => a >= b
!(a <= b) => a > b

Also fix some minor bugs where necessary parentheses would not be produced during sql generation.

Use generic ReadValue in update pipeline and key factories

This change allows cached delegates to be created that will call the generic IValueReader.ReadValue method using the type of the property. This means that when a RelationalTypedValueReader is used the generic GetFieldValue method will be called on the underlying data reader, thereby giving the provider the contextual information needed to create objects of the correct type in cases where this cannot be determined by the database metadata alone.

This mechanism is being used in the update pipeline and for key generation. It is not yet being used in query or for reading shadow state properties.

Cleanup DbContextOptions and factor out builder

This change cleans up the DbContextOptions classes, the way they are built and handled, and the way extensions interact. There is now a DbContextOptionsBuilder class that is used in AddEntityFramework and OnConfiguring. This is used to create DbContextOptions objects which can be passed to the DbContext constructor and/or resolved from DI. From the app perspective everything works pretty much the same except that the DbContextOptions resolved from DI is no longer cloned before being passed to OnConfiguring. However, if OnConfiguring then does anything to change the options it will effectively result in the options being cloned at this time. The DbContextOptions themselves are effectively immutable.

All additional options are now added through extensions, and the way extensions add added/updated has been simplified a bit to have easier APIs and to decouple more cleanly from the raw options that are handled by DbContextOptions itself.

Auto configuring of a single data store now happens right after OnConfiguring is called, rather than later when a data store is selected. This is cleaner and means data store selection doesn't need to mutate options.

It is now possible to depend on non-generic DbContextOptions in your DbContext constructor, but a generic DbContextOptions for your context type must be used. Non-generic DbContextOptions is now abstract.

DbContextOptions parsing is now performed by a DI service.

Fix to #1747 - Multi-select with Contains() does not generate SQL

Fix is to translate Where(c => [list_of_constants].Constains(c.SomeProperty)) to
c.SomeProperty IN ( [list_of_constants)

We also translate !Contains... into NOT IN. Relinq converts Contains call into subquery, so we are detecting this pattern in the FilteringExpressionTreeVisitor and translate it accordingly. Argument to contains in this case will always be in the form of parameter. Parameter values are wired in during SQL generation.
Refactored EqualityPredicateOptimizer to factor in In/NotIn nodes created via Contains in the optimizations. Removed

Additional refactoring: NotInExpression and InExpressionBase, recognizing pattern NotExpression(InExpression(..)) instead.

Stop resolving Database facade API directly from DI

We want to resolve DI services by contract, and specifically by interfaces for dynamic data store services. However, we want facade classes to have explicitly implemented interfaces for people writing extension methods on them. These two things were in conflict. This change adds a simple factory abstraction to allow a contract to be resolved from DI that will generate the facade API. We might also consider not extending RelationalDatabase, etc from Database since this is not really required anymore, but that is not done here.

Introduce interfaces for dynamic data store services

This change introduces interfaces for all data store services (except Database) that are dynamically selected based on the data store that is being used by the current context instance. This makes our DI use cleaner because we are always resolving these services by a contract type, rather than sometimes by the default implementation we have.

In addition, data store-specific interfaces have also been created for these servics. This means that these are also resolved from DI by contract and any replacement no longer needs to extend from our implementation.

Currently we still have the "empty interfaces" because we are regsitering everything in DI by data-store specific contract even if there is currently no difference between the base-specific contract and the data-store specific contract. This makes replacement of the service with a data-store specific one very easy. However, a further change may make this unnecessary and I will investigate that.

Database has not been updated to use a contract interface because it is a facade API that is resolved from DI. I'm going to investigate this further and will likely change the code to stop resolving facade APIs from DI since I believe the extension mechanisms we have don't require this and not doing it will allow the different goals of the two types of API to be better met.

Allow direct constructor injection of dynamic services

This change removes the DbContextService class and instead registers DI functions that return dynamic services directly. This means that the services can be used directly in constructor arguments, and consequentially are resolved eagerly rather than lazily.

The most significant change from this is that DataStore could not longer depend on StateManager. This was resolved by doing some DI-enabling in query, since query was using DataStore to obtain most of its services. There is probably more that can be done to reduce DataStore coupling by DI-enabling query.

In addition to this change, the DataStoreServices implementations of providers are now implemented using ServiceLocator. This is a good change because DataStoreServices is now used only as the source for functions registered in DI that allow the constructor injection to work, and using service locator avoids coupling of all the data store services together in one place where they will all be loaded together.

Other changes were in tests where we were relying on lazy evaluation never happening to avoid having to have valid services. The eager evaluation means we always need a valid service.

fix to #1642 -Query :: Bad sql generated for query with bool parameter in filter

Error is for queries that are using bool parameter (closure) in a filter query. We would produce query like: SELECT c.Id FROM Customers as c WHERE @prm, which is invalid.

Fix is to apply similar compensation as we do for constant bools in filter, to produce query like: SELECT c.Id FROM Customers as c WHERE @prm = 1

Fix to #1251 - join + orderby + count produces invalid sql

Problem was that we would procude queries like:
SELECT COUNT(*)
FROM [Customer] AS [c]
ORDER BY [c].[Id]

which were invalid, because column on which you order should be projected, and we project COUNT(*) instead. However, ordering is redundant when querying for count and could be removed.

Fix is to remove any orderings when querying for count.

There was another small issue that has been fixed - when calculating whether client eval for filter is required, we would use a common variable for the entire query. This could cause issues if multiple filters were present in the query, some being client eval, some being server eval. Fix is to use a variable local to the particular filter operation, and |= the results with the global variable. CR: Andrew

Make value generators share fewer features and allow scoped value generators

Conceptually a value generator is a singleton service that should persist across scopes. This is the way they were previously implemented. However, this makes it impossible for a value generators to use scoped services, such as the connection, unless those services are passed to the generator instance. This change allows scoped value generators to be created such that they can use scoped services. This allows a generator to be created that can use, for example, the connection. However, care must then be taken to ensure that the state of the generator persists across scopes (for which a cache is provided.)

In addition, two of the reusable features of value generators--the ability to cache by something other than a property, and the ability to use a pool of generators--have been removed. These are now built into the HiLo/Sequence generator, which was the only generator currently using these features. Other generators cannot be pooled and are always cached by property unless they also implement these services inside their own code.

Fix to multiple include bugs - #1433, #1478, #1487 #1488

Problem was that if a query was executed multiple times, or after another query, some of the entities were stored in state manager and not in the reader buffer. However when accessing PK/FK we were always using the buffered readers. This could cause multitude of errors, e.g buffer being empty, trying to access element of the reader that doesn't exist, is of a wrong type, or worst case - cause data corruption.

Fix is to mark first element of the buffer for a given entity with a null value, if that entity is already in state manager - later, when we try to retrieve the keys we check for that null, and if we find it we use state manager instead.

Fix to #1393 - data corruption for multi level include with optional and required relationships

Problem was that for include queries we would produce INNER JOIN for required relationships and OUTER JOIN for optional relationships. However for multi-level navigations this could cause data corruption. If one navigation was optional, all consequent joins should be OUTER JOINs as well, otherwise incorrect number of rows could be returned. Fix is to only produce INNER JOINs if there was no OUTER JOIN produced before.

fix to include bugs:

#1452 - Multiple multi-level collection/reference Include can fail
#1460 - "Sequence contains more than one matching element" thrown in some cases of multi level include

#1452 - problem appears in include queries in which Id columns of Included entities have same name. When this happens, we uniquefy them (see #1362). However, for more complex multi-level include, we use those keys in sort clause in one stage of the include but then we need to uniquefy it in the stage that comes after. This would result in SQL that tried to apply alias in the sort clause which is invalid. Fix is to not generate the alias for the order by during sql generation. Also another issue around this area was that we were passing original column name rather than aliased one to the order clause in the SelectExpression.

#1460 - problem appears in multi-level include queries that include same entity type multiple times in the chain. We uniquefy the names, however when constructing join conditions we only have column original name and table it comes from. This would lead to errors, since we assumed there would always be only one column in the projection list, that would match the criteria for the join condition. Fix is to use the last column from the list of candidates - as we always stick the column from the most recently joined table at the end of the projection list.

Remove async overloads of Add and related code

Based on API review decision. Async versions of Add were included because when value generation is being used it may occasionally be necessary to make a database call to get a new sequence. However, there are two problems with this:
* It is not possible to have async code paths for all places where Add may be called. For example, if a new entity is detected from a call to INotifyPropertyChanged.
* All higher-level code paths that may call Add need to have async versions as well. This spreads quicky--for example DetectChanged, AttachGraph.

There are two options for an application that wants to ensure that every possible database call is async:
* Use a value generation strategy that never queries the database on Add
* Make the database call to get sequence values explicitly and set key values directly before Adding new entities.

Functional tests for graph manipulation and fixes to fixup bugs

These tests cover adding, removing, and changing relationships between entities. Dimensions are:
* Multiplicity (1:1, 1:*)
* Required/optional relationships
* PK <-> PK and PK <-> FK
* New (Added) entities or existing (Unchanged) entities
* Changing relationship at principal end, dependent end, or using FK
* PK principal keys or alternate principal keys

Note that these tests do no cover deleting entities, composite keys, or unidirectional navigations. Also, we don't yet handle conceptually null FKs.

fix to issue #1457 - "ExecuteReader requires an open and available Connection" thrown when trying to execute a query after a failed query executed before

Problem was that in some cases we would try to close connection more times than we tried to open it. This would result in a corrupted state that would prevent opening the connection by subsequent queries.
This could happen in case of multi-level include. During that scenario we create multiple queries (data readers) and combine their results together in the end. Once data is retrieved there is a cleanup code that disposes of the participating enumerators.
However, if one of the queries throw or at some point during Include chain there is no more data (i.e. collection is empty) - it is possible that not all readers will be used, and therefore connection will be opened fewer times than assumed.
Cleanup code was trying to close connection once per expected reader, regardless of whether it was being used or not - which lead to this bug.

Fix is to only attempt to close connection if the associated reader has been used. Additionally I made QueryingEnumerable.Dispose() method idempotent.

Implements the basic caching architecture sans funcletization - It works because relinq partially evaluates captured variables during query parsing. We end up with a single cache entry per partially evaluated expression tree. Funcletization is TBD..

Changing relationship configuration API to separate calls for each end.

The new API will also avoid overriding existing configuration implicitly. E.g. calling Entity<Order>.HasOne(e => e.Details); will by default configure the relationship as one to many with Order as the dependent end. However If there was already a one to one relationship involving the "Details" navigation then the existing relationship and the associated FK will not be changed as no conflicting configuration has been explicitly specified.

Fix to issue 1362 - multi level include may produce invalid SQL
In some cases of multi level include we would try to project columns from two tables, which may lead to invalid queries if those properties happen to have the same name. Fix is to uniquefy the columns using projection aliases where necessary (if the affected subquery it itself aliased).
Also, in case of aliasing we can no longer rely on column names when building join equality expressions - instead we extract the projected columns and use their alias when applicable, rather than original column name.

Fixing ef migration add help. Adding the ability to specify subcommands in the print help command

Fix handling of null entity keys and interaction with query (Issues #1292, #1093)

The main issue was that SimpleNullableEntityKeyFactory would return null instead of NullEntityKey. However, the changes go deeper than this. Specifically:
- SimpleEntityKeyFactory had been updated to handle nulls, making SimpleNullableEntityKeyFactory pointless. It was original intended that SimpleEntityKeyFactory would avoid all null checking for cases where the data is asserted by the model to be non-null. This didn't work out because of the need to use the primary key factory with data that comes from the foreign key, and hence may be null. The result is that SimpleNullableEntityKeyFactory is not needed and should have been removed, but was still being used in some cases.
- The way query interacts with the state manager was changed such that the state manager now never materializes entity instances. Instead it always does materialization (but ignoring shadow state) and then passes the materialized entity to the state manager using StartTracking. This means that GetOrMaterializeEntry is now never used and has been removed.
- Per Issue #1093, StartTracking did not validate that the key was non-null-this check has been added. Also, a check has been added that if the entity with the given identity is already being tracked then it must actually be the same instance. No tests failed after adding these checks, which indicates that query is correctly doing identity resolution.

Create appropriate sidecars for store generated values (Issue #1303)

The code creates a sidecar for properties that may get a store generated value because a temporary value generator is used either directly or for the root principal in the case of FKs, or the property or the property is directly marked to be computed or get a store default. Note that the actual value of the property is not used (as it was previously) since it can change and hence a store value may look like it is not needed when creating the sidecar, but then it may actually be needed if the value later changes later.

This required that value generators be changed to indicate whether or not they generate temporary values without actually generating a value. This means a value generator must either generate temps or not and cannot switch, but this seems like a reasonable limitation.

Update handling of snapshots and ensure DetectChanges is only used when required (Issue #731)

The logic around when to snapshot original values was written before a lot of the relationship fixup and DetectChanges code. These changes revisit that code to improve and test the logic for determined if and when snapshots are required.

We make eager snapshots (as soon as the entity is tracked) for original values and relationship properties and navigations when the entity does not implement INotifyPropertyChanging. In addition, we take a collection snapshot for any collection that does not implement INotifyCollectionChanged. However, since INotifyCollectionChanged is not actually supported yet we currently treat all collections as if they do not implement this interface. See issue #445.

DetectChanges is needed for any entity that does not implement INotifyPropertyChanged, and also if an entity has a collection that does not implement INotifyCollectionChanged. As above, it is currently assumed that no collection does because of issue #445.

Auto-DetectChanges (Issue #745)

- Allow auto-DetectChanges to be switched off
- Call DetectChanges automatically from SaveChanges, Entry, and Entries, unless it has been switched off
- Create async version so that async Add can be called when needed. Note that as discussed, the async version is never called from Entry or Entries to avoid even more async API. Guidance will be to call DetectChangesAsync manually before Entry or Entries if it may add new objects and if it is important that this happen asynchronously.

Make the relationship API on InternalEntityBuilder preserve and respect the configuration source.

Relationships are uniquely identified by the navigation and foreign key properties, i.e. when configuring a relationship that shares a navigation property or the foreign key property set with an existing one they will be merged into one relationship according to their configuration sources, if same the last one wins.

Allow principals and dependents using key generation to be added in any Order

See issues #1271 and #1207. The main issue here is that if a dependent entity is added to the context before its principal has been added then the primary key value of the principal has not yet been generated. This means that people need to be careful which order to add things in, which in turn means that AttachGraph would not work in some scenarios,

The fix is to find the value generator for the principal of the relationship (possibly traversing several relationships to do so) and use it to generate a temporary key for the dependent entity. When the principal is finally added fixup will happen and the actual principal value will be propagated down to the dependents. The value generator for the ultimate principal needs to be used (instead of some other generator) so that key conflicts in the generated values do not happen as values propagate down.

Fix to issue 1220 - Queries with join and count (or other result operators) were broken.

Problem was in the result operator translation, where we tried prune CreateValueReader and CreateEntity calls - replace it with the reader that we get from the database query. We should remove the first (outermost) occurrence of CreateValueReader/CreateEntity, but instead we were removing the innermost one. Reason for that is that we were matching it based on source scope that was passed to the visitor and we were passing the incorrect one. Fix is to pass the correct query scope (i.e. one that would match the outermost CreateValueReader/CreateEntity node. CR: Diego

fix to issue 1293 - Include :: data corruption when doing query with include on One-to-One navigation property
For One to One PK-PK relationship we were creating INNER JOINs, which could result in entities not being returned for Include query if their referenced entity was null. Fix is to produce LEFT JOIN instead for One to One Include queries. CR: Andriy

Add higher-level AttachGraph methods

Currently two methods, with async overloads:
- AttachGraph: Adds each entity if its key value is not set, otherwise attaches the entity as Unchanged.
- UpdateGraph: Adds each entity if its key value is not set, otherwise attaches the entity as Modified.

We can discuss if both behaviors are needed, and if so whether it should be a single method with a flag.

These methods make use of an implementation of IEntityAttacher and there is a factory to get the IEntityAttacher to use for attach/update. This means that the defaults can be changed by registering a different factory in DI.

The default key checking is exposed as a IsKeySet property on EntityEntry, so it is easy to use this functionaliy either in the AttachGraph delegate or in implementations of IEntityAttacher.

Add key generators for common key types and add checks ensuring tempt keys are replaced on SaveChanges

See Issue #1271. This change adds the infrastructure for any key property to have a value generator and adds an exception for when a temporary key value is still set when the state of the object is changed to Unchanged, Modified, or Deleted. This will happen if SaveChanges is given temp values and doesn't generate real values.

This change does not include a convention to make any key property have GenerateValueOnAdd, although the convention that detects keys now sets it for any key detected.

Use TryAdd in AddXxx methods to only add services if not already present.

Issue #956 and also see pull request #1129.

This change updates all of our AddXxx methods to use TryAdd when adding to the service collection such that only services that are not already registered will be registered. This also means that the code we had to check the service collection for "hosting" services is no longer needed.

Note that services for which it is expected that multiple instances can be registered (e.g. listeners and data sources) must not use TryAdd since otherwise only the first registered will be used.

Make database creation for SQL Server more resilient to failures

Issue #985. The change here is to call the equivalent of Exists always immediately after creating the database. If this fails with one of the "transient" errors that we have encountered, then sleep for a bit and retry the exists check. Repeat until it passes or until we've waited so long we just give up.

Also made a similar change in the test code used to create databases since it doesn't use the EF mechanisms.

Currently executing a squence of Migrations operations to create a database will not use this mechanism--will file a bug on this.

Change casing of SQLite classes (Issue #1047)

Current casing matches the external SQLite ADO.NET provider that we don't use at all, but does not conform to any naming standards. A few of us talked and came to the conclusion that Sqlite would be better. Explaining: SQLite is not two words--i.e. it's not SQ Lite or SQL Ite, which means that SqLite is wrong and SQLite is wrong. So it must be one (weird) word and hence casing should be Sqlite.

Stop using DbContextConfiguration directly in most tests and remove from Context

This is part of Issue #641 which is about cleaning up the use of DbContextConfiguration. DbContextConfiguration is intended to help resolve dynamic services--that is, services for which the actual type/instance of service to use depends on the current context configuration. However, it has gradually spread throughout the code as a general purpose service locator. This causes dependencies to be hidden and creates a lot of coupling to DbContextConfiguration throughout the code, so I am making a set of changes to help fix this.

The previous changes removed most dependencies in the code on DbContextConfiguration. This meant that the tests were now using it only as an easy way to get a service provider setup with everything needed for an in-scope configured context instance. This change makes this more explicit both in the product code and in the tests that use it by removing the Configuration property from the context and replacing it instead with a hidden property for the scoped service provider. This explicitly exposes the fully setup scoped service locator which is very useful for testing and for writing extensions to the context that may require arbitrary services.

Also cleaned up a few remaining places where DbContextConfiguration was being used directly as a service locator--notably for the MigrationScaffolder and MigrationAssembly.

Making Ignore behave the same independently of the order relative to other configuration.

If a property or entity was added and ignored explicitly an exception will be thrown.
If a property or entity was added and ignored through conventions or data annotations the property will be present on the entity.
If a property is ignored and removed after conventions or data annotations added keys, foreign keys or indexes referencing it they will be removed as well.
The same applies to entity types and foreign keys referencing them.

Cleanup interaction of DbSet and DbContextConfiguration

This is part of Issue #641 which is about cleaning up the use of DbContextConfiguration. DbContextConfiguration is intended to help resolve dynamic services--that is, services for which the actual type/instance of service to use depends on the current context configuration. However, it has gradually spread throughout the code as a general purpose service locator. This causes dependencies to be hidden and creates a lot of coupling to DbContextConfiguration throughout the code, so I am making a set of changes to help fix this.

In this case the DbSet needs to have access to DbContextConfiguration, through the context, because sets are created eagerly before the scoped service provider is created, but are then initialized lazily in the scope the first time they are used.

Decouple value generation from DbContextConfiguration and state entries

This is part of Issue #641 which is about cleaning up the use of DbContextConfiguration. DbContextConfiguration is intended to help resolve dynamic services--that is, services for which the actual type/instance of service to use depends on the current context configuration. However, it has gradually spread throughout the code as a general purpose service locator. This causes dependencies to be hidden and creates a lot of coupling to DbContextConfiguration throughout the code, so I am making a set of changes to help fix this.

Value generation is special in that it needs to be a singleton service such that values span context scopes for things like the in-memory provider and for management of sequence blocks. However, the generation process may sometimes need to make use of the current data store, and hence the current context scope. This means that a value generator cannot just depend on any scoped data service that it needs because it is itself a singleton. Therefore, the generation methods are passed the current data store services such that they can be used if necessary.

In addition, since the state entry was no longer being used to get access to the current scope it meant that decoupling from the state entry was possible. This decoupling in general made the code simpler and made more apparent the fact that the ForeignKeyValueGenerator wasn't really a value generator and hence no longer tries to be one and is handled separately. This is cleaner especially since it was being partially handled separately anyway.

Make Database not depend on DbContextConfiguration

This is part of Issue #641 which is about cleaning up the use of DbContextConfiguration. DbContextConfiguration is intended to help resolve dynamic services--that is, services for which the actual type/instance of service to use depends on the current context configuration. However, it has gradually spread throughout the code as a general purpose service locator. This causes dependencies to be hidden and creates a lot of coupling to DbContextConfiguration throughout the code, so I am making a set of changes to help fix this.

This change introduces the idea of registering delegates for dynamic services using the mechanism added recently to the DI abstraction. This allows dynamic services to be depended on in constructors in the normal way. However, since these dynamic services can result in work being done to initialize and build the service the delegates are generally registered to create LazyRef<TService> and so this should be depended on. This allows, for example Database to depend on the current model by depending on LazyRef<IModel> but the model will only be built if the database actually makes use of it.

Remove incomplete UseXxx service methods

These were intended as a form of sugar for replacing services. However, they have not been updated with new services, are used inconsistently, and don't seem to provide real value over just using the normal DI methods. We already know that we need to consider the common extensibility story with some form of sugar, but I don't think this is it, so cleaning this out for now.

Make Database facade use more consistent across data stores

This is part of Issue #641 which is about cleaning up the use of DbContextConfiguration. DbContextConfiguration is intended to help resolve dynamic services--that is, services for which the actual type/instance of service to use depends on the current context configuration. However, it has gradually spread throughout the code as a general purpose service locator. This causes dependencies to be hidden and creates a lot of coupling to DbContextConfiguration throughout the code, so I am making a set of changes to help fix this.

There are two main reasons for this change:
- Ensure that the correct provider-specific Database facade is always used even when multiple providers have registered services
- Change the way the ApplyMigrations method is implemented such that, in an upcoming change, it can be decoupled from direct use of DbContextConfiguration.

Splitting the low-level ValueGeneration enum; Issue #704

From issue:

ValueGeneration.OnAdd means generate a value for the property in the state manager when the entity is put into the Added state. It doesn't have a direct impact on the update pipeline.

ValueGeneration.OnAddAndUpdate doesn't have any meaning in the state manager and doesn't make use of value generators at all. It tells the update pipeline that the value is computed on the store and so should always be obtained from the store for both inserts and updates.

These things are therefore orthogonal and don't really belong in the same enum. It might be cleaner to just have two bool flags on the API surface. For example, GenerateValueOnAdd and IsStoreComputed.

Allow data store selection to happen in OnConfiguring (Issue #932)

Or: Attack of the Semi-Deep-Memberwise-Copies

Previously the common scenario for DbContextOptions was that a new object would be created for each context instance. This allowed it to be mutated in OnConfiguring such that, for example, a different data store could be selected each time. There was also the case where DbContextOptions was put into DI or passed to the constructor, in which case OnConfiguring would be called once and the options would be locked.

The recent changes to options means that the common case is now for DbContextOptions to be in DI. This means that this single object is shared by all context instance created by the app. This results in two problems:
* The locking now happens almost always, effectively making it impossible to dynamically select options in OnConfiguring
* The dynamic selection is not thread safe, but it can be executed by multuple threads all sharing the single object.

The solution is to clone DbContextOptions before passing it to OnConfiguring. This means that all context instance can share common options and also can dynamically change those options in OnConfiguring without impacting other instances. This restores the previous functionality, removes the thread safety issue in the normal path, and also means that locking is no longer required.

Fix break that made SQL Server keys non-clustered by default

Or: Nuclear collapse of the tri-valued cluster bomb

Issue #911
The clustered annotation is now SQL Server specific and default to null, meaning not specified. The Migrations database builder does not have the concept of not specified and was interpreting null as false. This resulted in keys being created explicitly as non-clustered. This change makes null be treated as clustered by default to revert the break, but note that the core/Migrations difference in how clustering is supported still needs to be addressed--see issue #879

Random sequential access...

Add SQL Server-specific model APIs for sequences and clustering

This adds SQL Server-specific fluent and core metadata APIs as discussed in the design meeting here: https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFramework/wiki/Design-Meeting-Notes---October-2,-2014

The sequence APIs are different from discussed in the meeting because they now more explicitly separate the use of sequences for value generation from the definition of sequences in the relational model. The definition of sequences now has a relational-specific fluent API and this is the only place where characteristics of the sequence can be changed. The model can then be setup to use sequences for value generation, as can each property.

This code doesn't include connecting up the new annotations to the Migrations code.

fix to issue 788 - Tracking entities has a discrepancy in behavior between sync and async. For sync, objects returned to the customer have the same reference as ones created and stored in state manager. For async, we do create and store objects in state manager, but return the original ones to the customer. This could cause errors for some scenarios (issue 788) - we would end up with same entity being tracked twice which then would lead to a validation error. CR: Andrew

Initial work on provider-specific Code First and core metadata extensions.

This is the initial work for relational and SQL Server extensions. It doesn't yet replace what we currently have--that code still exists as well. Write-only extensions can be used for the fluent APIs together with read/write extensions for mutable metadata and read-only extensions for metadata interfaces.

The following things still need to be done:
- Extensions that are specific to SQL Server and not just overrides of the relational extensions  (Clustered, UseSequence, UseIdentity)
- Extensions for ATS
- The relational model builder
- DefaultValue is not implemented because it really needs non-string annotations.

FixupSpeedup episode one - the slowdown menace

Entity fixup is still costly but this changeset is making it 10x faster by getting some low hanging fruit:
  - Reduction of allocations by changing .ToArray() by .ToList() when the collection is temporary.
  - Caching of values that are used constantly.
  - Accessing the same property repeatedly inside loops avoided.

The caching will probably have to be revisited in a future iteration. Here are some of the numbers I obtained:

RelationshipFixup before the change
1153252ms total (100 iterations)
17920ms 95th percentile
20988ms 99th percentile
20988ms 99.9th percentile

RelationshipFixup after the change
138670ms total (100 iterations)
1652ms 95th percentile
1944ms 99th percentile
1944ms 99.9th percentile

The closest EF6 test we have is objectctx-fixup-fk-poco

Support store-generated default values

This change allows a property to be marked as using store-generated default values. If no value has been set for the property when the update pipeline inserts the entity the update pipeline will read the value generated from the store. If a value is specified explicitly it will be inserted. This is essentially the same behavior has used for generating keys except that it doesn't involve value generation on Add.

Note that the generation of default constraints in the database by Migrations is not yet implemented so these will need to be setup manually for now.

Also not supported yet is the ability to use this in updates where the semantics are a bit more nuanced.

EDMLib v4? (Metadata robustness and non-primary keys)

(This change looks big, but the only really substantive changes are in EntityType.cs)

This change adds non-primary keys as a first-class part of the model as per issue #537. In looking at this it became clear that it was time to add some more robustness to the core metadata to help prevent the model getting into inconsistent state--for example, removing keys that are being referenced by foreign keys. Most of this change is about adding that robustness. Specifically:
- Be explicit and consistent about being able to either find and existing metadata item or create a new one if it doesn't yet exist. This matches the way we tend to use metadata, especially from fluent APIs and conventions. It helps protect against a couple of bugs we have had recently where duplicate items (properties or keys) were added by mistake. The methods are currently called GetOrAddXxx, but we can discuss other ideas.
- Error checking for things like CLR properties actually existing
- Checks to prevent removal of items that are currently still being referenced in the model

Paul Daniels or Penn & Teller? (Remove relationship APIs from BasicModelBuilder)

We decided last week that we should have a basic model builder that would map closely to the underlying metadata and would not use any conventions together with the more traditional model builder that has sugar API and makes use of conventions. The relationship APIs (OneToMany, OneToOne, etc.) cannot function without conventions and so should live only on the convention-based builder. In doing this the inheritance, overrides, and "new" classes and methods became increasingly difficult to handle, so most of this change is a refactoring  which hopefully makes things easier to handle and evolve.

Some possible approaches I looked into were:
- Deriving the convention builder from the basic builder. This didn't work very well because of the need for changing of types in the sub-builders, resulting in a lot of "new" methods. It also means we can add things to the convention API, but cannot remove things. For example, currently the convention API has both the sugar relationship APIs and the lower-level ForeignKey API, but we may choose to not expose the ForeignKey API.
- Also, we currently derive the generic builders from the non-generic builders. This works quite well, although the need for a base class makes it harder to work with, and this leaks into the code for extension methods which have quite involved generic type definitions using the base types.

The best approach I have been able to come up with makes use of a couple of patterns that have worked well in the past:
- Split the actual logic of model building into implementation classes. These are not specific to the convention or basic builders which can then make use of any functionality that makes sense. This allows the public API to be decoupled from the implementation so that we can present the public API that we want while keeping the logic in a single place and factored appropriately for the implementation. Traditionally these implementations would have been internal, but I have made them public in keeping with the EF7 philosophy, just in an internal namespace.
- The actual basic and convention builders are now separate and don't derive from each other. This does result in some code duplication, but it is specifically API code and not implementation code, and it allows for flexibility in the two APIs as described above.
- Conversion operators between the two types of builders are easy to create and I added them at the top-level, but we should discuss whether these are really useful.
- I wanted to make API extensions relatively easy to write and also allow a single extension to be used for both the basic and conventional builders. To facilitate this there are interfaces for each of the builders that can be targeted by extension methods. These interfaces provide easy access to the metadata item being targeted (e.g. EntityType), the model, and the Annotation API. This allows extensions to be written in a very similar way to the core fluent API. It does not provide direct access to all the fluent methods of the builders because doing so tends to make the interface/type definitions overly complex. Also, the fluent methods available are different for the different builders. If the fluent methods need to be used it is still possible to write specific extension methods for specific builders.

That name no longer has any meaning for me... (Remove parameterless overloads of ForeignKey and ReferencedKey)

After discussion of this API we decided that the semantics of these overloads were ambiguous as to whether they were for just specifying the end or indicating that the FK should be created explicitly in shadow state. Given that the only real value is to avoid having to be explicit about either the FK or PK in cases where the principal/dependent need to be flipped, we decided it was better to remove these overloads.

Blue Screen of Curable Illness

Initial cut of middleware to provide a custom error page when a database exception occurs in an ASP.NET vNext. The error page is displayed when there is some action that can be taken with migrations that may fix the error (applying migrations, scaffolding a new migration, etc.). If the action is just applying the existing migrations then we also include the ability to apply them from the page. This makes use of another piece of middleware that can apply migrations.

This functionality will only ever be enabled in local dev mode by default (same as other diagnostics pages for ASP.NET vNext).

This is just an initial cut, things that still need to happen are:
 - Better error handling/validation in middleware
 - Tests
 - Handling context not being registered in DI
 - Styling for error page (currently it just has very simple styling largely copied from the existing ASP.NET vNext error page)

Time for another injection... (Refactoring of DataStoreSource)

This change splits and modifies DataStoreSource so that:
- Constructor injection is used in some places we were using the service provider directly
- The provider services (that need to be accessed abstracting based on the configuration of the current context instance) are separated from the mechanism of selection
- Allows common types to be used while still allowing extension with a specific type. For example, only the ATS provider currently has custome conventions. This means all other providers can use a common ModelBuilder/conventions. But if I want to extend EF to add a custom convention just for SQL Server I can now do that by creating a dervived SqlServerDataStoreServices class and using my new ModelBuilder/conventions in the constructor. All other providers will continue to use the same conventions. This means that for cases like that we don't need to create a derived class simply to allow external extension.

This allows all the configuration for a given entity type to be placed in a nested closure.

The kangaroos are hopping... (Set FK values based on referenced principal on Add)

EF7 requires that all tracked entities have a unique primary key, even if it is temporary. Value generators are often used to obtain this primary key value. However, for identifying relationships (where the PK of an entity is also an FK and is completely or partially defined by the PK at the principal end of the relationship) the value used cannot be generated independently because it must match the principal PK. This change adds a value generator for FKs that uses navigation properties to find the principal and then takes the FK values from that principal. This makes it much easier to add a graph of entities without worrying about setting FK/PK values explicitly.

Note that it is necessary to find the principal in order to get the key for a dependent in an identifying relationship. This means that the principal must be added first so that it gets a valid key, or must at least have a valid key set with a direct reference from the dependent.

Sidecars 7, Brazil 1... (Propagate generated principal values to FKs on SaveChanges)

Some primary/principal key values are generated in the store when the entity is saved--for example, for Identity columns. These values are written back into the state entry by the update pipeline. Foreign keys that reference these principal key values also need to be updated with the generated values so that the entire graph stays in sync and so that subsequent commands issued by the update pipeline make use of the newly generated values. Also, if the save transaction is not committed, then these generated values should be discarded.

Values written into the state manager by the update pipeline are placed in a temporary transparent sidecar so that they can be discarded later. When a change is detected (or notification is made) that a principal property has changed, then the state manager now finds dependents and updates FK values appropriately. These are also written into the transparent sidecar so that the update pipeline can read them like normal values for subsequent commands, but the values can still be discarded if SaveChanges fails.

Distant relatives... (Move relational-only API out of top-level Database class and into extension methods.)

From design meeting notes:
Currently the top-level runtime database creation APIs in EF7 are:
- Database.Create
- Database.CreateTables
- Database.Delete
- Database.Exists
- Database.HasTables
- Database.EnsureCreated
- Database.EnsureDeleted

The first five of these are simple operations while the Ensure... methods are composed from the simple operations. The Ensure... methods cover the common pattern for database creation in testing and rapid prototyping. They can also be reasonably implemented across multiple different types of data store.

The simple methods are not so easy to abstract in a meaningful way beyond relational databases. For example, knowing that a database exists but has no tables is useful in relational providers since it is common for an empty database to be provisioned for which EnsureCreated will detect that it is empty (HasTables returns false) and then appropriately create the tables. But for other types of store it may not be possible to check whether or not the database has tables. Therefore we will move the simple operations to be relational-only and leave only EnsureCreated and EnsureDeleted on the common surface.

You can't fire me because I quit! (Change from Added to Deleted results in detached entity)

See issue #351. When an entity is in the Added state it means that it doesn't exist in the database and should be inserted during SaveChanges. If the state is then changed to Deleted this would mean delete an entity that doesn't exist in the database, which will fail. In the EF6 stack we instead detach the entity in this case so that it is just never inserted. This change implements the same behavior in EF7.

Bridging the generation gap... (Integrate value generators with data stores)

This change covers two main areas:
1. The StoreValueGenerationStrategy enum is replaced with two new enums--one to determine what kind of value generation to do when the entity is added to the context, and one to determine the kind of value generation that happens on the server when SaveChanges is called. A third enum for configuration of default value use is envisioned but is not included here.
2. Re-working of the generators and related infrastructure so that a data store can control which generator is used and so that a database connection from the session can be used in the value generation process.

More specifically:
- Each data store has a cache of generators that are being used. This allows generators to hold state, such as the next value to generate.
- For each logical generator the cache can contain a pool of actual generators. This is currently only used for SQL Server sequence generators so that multiple blocks can be used at once for a given sequence, which can in-turn reduce the chance that all requests are blocked waiting for a new block to be created on the server.
- Each generator type has its own factory which is responsible for creating an instance of the generator and also providing information used to manage the pool of generators--for example, the pool size and the key used to store the generators in the cache. So, for example, all SQL Server sequence generators could use the same sequence in the database in which case only a single pool would be used for all properties that use this sequence. Currently the default is to create a different database sequence for each table, but we can discuss whether or not this is the best default.
- Each data store also has a selector which is responsible for deciding which kind of generator to use based on the property type and associated metadata--basically whether or not the value should be generated on the client or on the server.

I believe that the SQL server sequence generator (and its pool) is not asynchronously thread-safe.

Some things that still need to be done:
- The fluent API for using store sequence is currently part of the code code, but it should probably be relational-only.
- Integration into Migrations is needed so that the store sequences will be created appropriately.
- No SQLite value generation yet

Magic emerges from simplicity... (Updates to database creation APIs)

The idea here is to follow a pattern of very simple, very non-magical, commands for the basic operations which can then be composed into more complex operations. The simple commands are:
- Exists: True if database exists; false if it doesn't
- HasTables: True if the database has any tables; false if it doesn't; potentially throw if the database doesn't exist
- Create: Create an empty database or potentially throw if a database with the given name already exists
- Delete: Delete an exist database or potentially throw if the database doesn't exist

None of these commands do existence checking because this has proven to be problematic in many situations and providing these building block commands thus allows the most flexibility for people to get the behavior they need without being dependent on things like exists checks that may not work. For example, you may have some mechanism in your app/infrastructure that tells you this is the first run and therefore the database cannot exist and needs to be created. With these commands this can still be mad to work even if there the exists check we would do does not work with the provider/environment you have.

All that being said, there are two common things that people do, so there are two higher-level composed commands provided out-of-the-box:
- EnsureCreated will create the database if it doesn't exist and create tables for the model if the database doesn't have any tables. It will do nothing if the database exists and has any tables in it.
- EnsureDeleted will delete the database if it exists or do nothing if the database doesn't exist.

SQL Server and In Memory implementations provided and tested, although not yet tested against SQL Azure. SQLite implementation provided but not tested since there are currently no SQLite tests.

Even beer pipelines exist... (Allow typed DbParameter creation in update pipeline)

Previously we were always inferring the type of DbParameter from the parameter value. This doesn't work in general because sometimes the type cannot be inferred (e.g. nulls) and sometimes the inference is wrong (e.g. DateTime => datetime instead of datetime2).

While trying to fix this is became apparent that the pipeline was doing many transformations to ad-hoc structures of tuples, string, and objects. This made it hard to get proper parameter creation because flowing the information to the right place requires updating all these data structures. I tried to simplify this and found that once simplified the use of the store model wasn't providing any value, so I removed this as well. This got to a point where value propagation, parameter creating, and command building became simpler. For example, there was no longer any need to map reader values back to state entries using column names because the order of the columns in the reader is known and can be used directly.

I also realized that the batching code we have will only ever create a batch of one and so isn't really exercised in the code. I left the code in place with a TODO. Discussions with others leads me to believe we will need to change the SQL that is generated in the future anyway and this may change the batching code as well. I did remove the code for reading non-identity computed keys--this will be added back as part of the work to rationalize how store-generated values are handled.

Quoting of identifiers was added.

Common store type mapping is now used for Migrations and the update pipeline. This is all in the base relational provider for now, but some of it will need to move into the SQL Server provider.

Ground and neutral are different... (Rewire services and configuration)

This change creates a separation between the services and settings for a context. This allows EF to work better with IServiceProvider instances created externally to EF which may change (due to scoping) each time used.

At the low level the steps for services are now:
- Create a ServiceCollection and configure services on it using EF and other extension methods
- Build the provider, either explicitly, or using facilities of MVC, etc.
- Expose a constrctor on the context for IServiceProvider and eitehr register the context type as transient on the DI container or create instances explicitly by passing in the IServiceProvider.

For settings, the OnConfiguring method can be used to set things like connection strings. Alternately, an EntityConfigurationBuilder can be used to create an EntityConfiguration with these kinds of settings. The IServiceProvider should be passed to EntityConfiguration.

When not using any external DI container or services, the EntityConfigurationBuilder can be used to also build the services, which will then be cached appropriately based on the services called. In this case the sugar WithServices method can be used to add providers or other types of service.

Note: Additional testing is needed for some of this code.

I like to ride my tricycle, I like to ride my trike... (Sidecars for storing alternate property values with state entries)

Original values are additional values that can be stored alongside the state entry and updated from or merged with the actual property values when appropriate. The update pipeline also needs to store additional values for properties that are store generated such that they can be used by the update pipeline while changes are being saved. These values cannot be stored directly in the state entries because they should be discarded if the save fails--or when the transaction is rolled back once we have transactions.

These two requirements are now captured into a single general-purpose concept of the sidecar on the state entry. This means that the state manager can be responsible for store value handling such that the data store/update pipeline doesn't need to do anything special--it just propagates values back into the state entry and can likewise read values from the state entry without fear of corrupting the state entry if the transaction is rolled back.

In addition, this change moves original values functionality out of the state entry for better separation of concerns, which in turn means that it is cleaner to change the storage for original values to be something other than just an object array if we determine that doing so is beneficial in terms of memory and/or speed.

...and I am a material...err...maybe not. (Allow strongly-typed non-boxing materialization)

This change introduces an abstraction between the data store and the materializer such that the generic non-boxing ReadField method can be used my the materializer to extract values without boxing. However, the abstraction can also be used to read all values using GetValues. This provides flexibility such that if GetValues is faster it can be used but for cases where GetValues is problematic or slower (e.g. because of type inference in SQLite) then the typed APIs can be used instead.

Note that we still call GetFieldValue<object> in some cases (e.g. when extracting shadow values or composite key values), but we could do similar code-gen as we do for materialization to avoid this.

Adds AcceptChanges to state entries which will:

AcceptAllChanges calls this for every entity in the state manager and SaveChanges calls AcceptAllChanges.

- "BackingField" annotation can be used to specify a field name
- FieldMatcher is essentially a convention that can be replaced to match fields differently.

Rename CreateIfNotExistsAsync to CreateAsync

This method always tries to create the schema. It uses an idempotent
script to create the physical database (so you can add schema to an
existing database) but it always tries to create the entire schema. I
missed this rename from the last commit.

Enable Database Creation

Enable creation of a SQL database from an IModel. Introduced a DataStoreCreator class as this functionality feels separate from DataStore itself (i.e. if we did combine them then SqlServerDataStore would have a dependency on ModelDiffer, MigrationSqlGenerator, etc.)

Needed to make a few changes as part of this:
- MigrationOperationSqlGenerator was building one large script for all operations but not all operations can be run in a script. Introducing a SqlStatement class and returning a set of these instead.
- In the old stack we handled generating the list of statements with a Statement method to add statements to the list, but that made extensibility hard. In these changes we flow the string builder thru the Visit methods so that derived generators can easily tweak the SQL (the SqlServerMigrationSqlGenerator is a good sanity test that this works better). The other nice side effect of this is that MigrationSqlGenerator is no longer stateful.
- The above change required changing the signature of Visit/Accept which meant the general purpose MigrationOperationVisitor would have needed to change signatures or not be used in this case.
- Introduced a SqlStatementExecutor, this needs to be padded out a lot and can be re-used across the stack. BTW to do that we also need to add more concepts (parameters etc.) to SqlStatement.
- Introduced the ability to not create the database when creating test databases (to allow testing creation of the physical database).

PrimitiveParametersGettingCivilised - replacing KeyValuePairs describing database columns in Update with types describing the database. Wiring Insert and Update operations to enable result propagation.

We're watching you... (Add support for change detection)

This checkin adds support for original value tracking and change detection to state entries.

We need original values for two purposes:
- Use in the update pipeline for concurrency tokens and graph ordering
- Detecting changes when using snapshot change tracking

Also, original values can be stored eagerly (snapshotting when then entity is materialized) or lazily (only when an attempt is made to change the current value).

We attempt to not store original values when not needed and to store them lazily when possible. This is fully possible for entities that implement both INotifyPropertyChanging and INotifyPropertyChanged.

If an entity implements only INotifyPropertyChanged but not INotifyPropertyChanging then only original values for updates are tracked by default but they are tracked eagerly because we don't know that a change is being made until it has already been made.

If an entity doesn't implement INotifyPropertyChanged, then original values for all properties are tracked eagerly so that DetectChanges can compare current and original values.

A flag on the entity type allows eager tracking of all original values for those users who always want original values in order to implement things like rejecting changes to entities.

Minty-fresh context services... (Create DI scope for context and services it uses, such as StateManager)

This change attempts to address several things:
- StateManager was getting big and involved in many responsibilities that it didn't really need to be involved with. I wanted to simplify the StateManager down to less stuff.
- One of the reasons that the StateManager was getting all this stuff was that it was used by state entries, and state entries don't want to carry around a lot of direct references to services because they are memory sensitive.
- The StateManager is scoped by context instance, and this was handled by using a factory. However, this prevents other services from depending on StateManager, becaus its not in the container, or the factory, because they would get a new instance, not the context one.

The proposed solution is to create a new configuration type which is created in context scope. This configuration derives from EntityConfiguration for global services and then adds sugar for scoped services. This provides the single object that state entries can hold onto and get whatever they need without relying on the StateManager. Also, it allows StateManager and other services to be created in this scope so that they can be properly injected into services that need them and the DI container will handle correct scoping.

Token cancellation tokens... (Update cancellation token pattern)

Need for (RS)-1-phenylpropan-2-amine... (Make creation of context instances fast)

EntitySet properties on the context are automatically initialized to appropriate EntitySet instances by the EntityContext constructor. It is important that this is very fast so that the overhead of creating a context instance is small and people will feel okay about using short-lived contexts. Also, I did this work in order to have some concrete idea of the perf impact of using a new configuration per context instance. For this case it is significant--approximately 50 times faster with caching on the configuration.

Please welcome Mr. Morden... (Supporting shadow state in the change tracker)

We primarily expect that an object model will be used to define and interact with EF. However, the plan for flexible mapping (such as many-to-many and hidden FKs) requires that properties or entire entities do not map directly to CLR properties or types. Instead the state of the properties for these entities existes in a seperaate buffer that travels with the state entry--sometimes known as shadow state. Approaching Z'ha'dum... (Moving towards metadata/state entries that support shadow state)

This includes:
- Back pointers to parent entity type with fixup for properties, FKs, and navigations
- Some more decoupling from CLR types--for example in Property
- Splitting LazyRef into thread safe and non-thread safe versions and using where appropriate
- Change of data structures to avoid sorting when consuming
- Exposing most metadata collections as IReadOnlyList instead of IEnumerable. This better matches the abstraction we want because it provides for cheap/natural counting and indexing, and helps reduce the need for defensive copying and the risk of accidental multiple enumerations of an IEnumerable. The downside it it doesn't allow streaming, but this seems like a reasonable tradeoff for this API.

He's a bit of a fixer-upper... (Initial work on navigations and fixup)

This change groups a few things together because they organically grew together. This makes the review a bit difficult--sorry for that. The high-level changes are:

- Further abstraction of the fluent/app-dev facing surface from the underlying implementation. There are two reasons for this. First, it creates a set of objects that are more suited for use by lower-level parts of the stack. This is similar to how Code First and DbContext currently have a set of objects backing the main fluent API. These types are all public so that these lower-level APIs can be both accessed and subsituted by provider code or other code as necessary. Second, moving lower-level functionality down keeps the top-level public surface uncluttered similar to how it is with DbContext now. However, the top-level surface currently has members to allow dropping-down to the lower-level surface when necessary/desired.
- Refactoring of the bit manipulation logic into its own type. This type is a struct to avoid heap allocation of an object for it. It is intended as purely an implementation detail of the StateEntry class.
- A modification to ForeignKey so that it can represent relationships where the principal end can be some unique key that is not the primary key.
- Some early work to support navigations between entities. Navigations are considered an updatable view over the FK properties. The updatable part isn't implemented yet. Simple fixup of entities when they begin tracking is implemented.

Old school bits and bytes... (Changes to property access in metadata/change tracker)

These changes cover two things:
1. Adding property indexes to the metadata API so that manipulation based on indexes such as in the change tracker is efficient.  I also did the bit-packing optimization for space in the change tracker.

2. Changing the data structures used in EntityType so that
- There is no pretense at thread-safety. (The code was not thread safe as it was although looked so at a superficial level. For example, if two threads both try to add different properties it could happen that only one of the properties got added.)
- Allow for sorting on property insert rather than removal
- Make Properties.Count fast because LINQ will use the IList optimization
- Provide a basis for the property indexes needed above

30 is the new 36 (Refactoring of compiled metadata)

This change again uses ideas from Emil to further reduce heap memory usage in the compiled model. The main idea is to only store references to the arrays themselves to the avoid the overhead of a heap-allocated wrapper object. Note that it would be possible to not store a reference for the keys but to build the enumerable each time it is needed, but we decided not to do this at least for now.

Additional benefits include fewer and easier to read/generate generated classes. This helps with the assembly size because there is assembly overhead for each type used.

Are you the Keymaster? (First attempt at wiring up change tracker to identity generation)

The idea here is to allow the change tracker to generate a key for new entities when added. Whether or not a key should be generated is determined by metadata on the property in the model. If it is known that key generation is required then the provider must be involved in selecting the appropriate key generator for the type of the property. Providers register an IdentityGeneratorFactory to handle this. However, the user can also register an IdentityGeneratorFactory to override the behavior for some or all properties of a given type.

We could also allow for an identity generator to be registered directly in the model, but this has implications for serialization of the model which is needed for both Migrations and compiled model state. It may be that there is some hook that allows runtime annotation of the model even if it has been compiled.

The configuration keeps the collection of active identity generators so that they can be shared by multiple context instances. This can also be changed in the configuration to allow for different levels of sharing.

Some additional testing still required.
